sdCardReaders.name: UGREEN SD Card Reader 2-in-1
sdCardReaders.pros: Versatile dual-connector design covers almost all modern devices. Very affordable.
sdCardReaders.cons: Protective caps are not attached and can be lost. UHS-I speed limit.
sdCardReaders.whyChooseThis: If you need a single reader that works with everything—from your MacBook to your iPhone 15 to your Android phone—this dual-connector design is unbeatable.
sdCardReaders.metaDescription: Review of the UGREEN 2-in-1 SD Card Reader. We test USB-C and USB-A transfer speeds, iPhone 15 compatibility, and build quality.

faq.q: Is the UGREEN 2-in-1 reader compatible with iPhone 15?
faq.a: Yes. The UGREEN CM185 has both USB-C and USB-A connectors. It works with iPhone 15, iPhone 15 Pro, and all USB-C iPhones using the USB-C adapter with OTG support. For iPhone 14 and earlier (Lightning ports), use a Lightning adapter.

faq.q: What transfer speed can I expect on MacBook Air?
faq.a: Real-world transfer speeds are 80-100 MB/s on most MacBook Air models with USB-C ports. Theoretical max is 104 MB/s (UHS-I), but actual speeds depend on the card and MacBook generation. MacBook Air M2/M3 achieves closer to 100 MB/s.

faq.q: Can this reader handle 4K video from GoPro and DJI drones?
faq.a: Yes, for standard 4K recording. The 104 MB/s speed works with most 4K cameras recording at 60fps. However, for 4K 120fps or high bitrate formats, upgrading to UHS-II (312 MB/s) readers like the SanDisk Extreme PRO is recommended.

faq.q: Does the UGREEN reader work with Android tablets and laptops?
faq.a: Yes, it supports both USB-C and USB-A Android devices. For USB-C Android phones and tablets, use the USB-C end. For older Android devices with USB-A ports, use the USB-A 3.0 end. OTG support is required for phone/tablet usage.

sdCardReaders.name: Muddy 4.3" LCD SD Card Viewer
sdCardReaders.pros: Allows reviewing footage in the field without a computer. Rugged rubberized grip.
sdCardReaders.cons: Low resolution screen. Does not support SDXC cards over 64GB.
sdCardReaders.whyChooseThis: Essential for hunters who want to check trail cams in the field without hauling a laptop or taking cards home.
sdCardReaders.metaDescription: Muddy 4.3-inch Trail Cam Viewer review. Does it handle 1080p video? Is the screen bright enough? Full field test results.

faq.q: Does the Muddy CRV43 work with trail cameras like Stealth Cam and Bushnell?
faq.a: Yes. The Muddy 4.3-inch viewer is compatible with SD and SDHC cards from most trail camera brands including Stealth Cam, Browning, Wildgame, and Bushnell. It does not support newer SDXC cards (128GB+).

faq.q: What's the battery life for reviewing photos in the field?
faq.a: Using 4x AAA alkaline batteries, you can review hundreds of photos per battery set. For extended field use, bring extra batteries or rechargeable AAs. Battery life varies by screen brightness setting (2-6 hours typical).

faq.q: Can I use the Muddy viewer in bright sunlight?
faq.a: The 4.3-inch LCD screen has 300+ nits brightness, adequate for shaded use but challenging in direct sunlight. For optimal viewing, use the viewer in shade or on overcast days. A sunshade is recommended for daytime field review.

faq.q: Does this viewer allow deleting and organizing photos?
faq.a: Yes. The Muddy CRV43 includes file management features to delete photos, organize into folders, and protect images from accidental deletion. Full SD card formatting is also supported.

sdCardReaders.name: Stealth Cam 4.3" SD Card Viewer
sdCardReaders.pros: Touchscreen allows for easier navigation than physical buttons. Zoom function helps identify details.
sdCardReaders.cons: Touchscreen can be difficult to use with heavy gloves.
sdCardReaders.whyChooseThis: The only trail cam viewer with touchscreen and zoom—perfect for hunters who need precision detail identification in the field.
sdCardReaders.metaDescription: Stealth Cam touchscreen SD card viewer review. Zoom, brightness, battery life, and field testing for trail camera users.

faq.q: Does the Stealth Cam touchscreen work in cold hunting conditions?
faq.a: Yes, but responsiveness degrades below 32°F. The touchscreen works in winter hunting but may require multiple taps or firmer pressure. Wear lightweight gloves that support touchscreen interaction for optimal winter use.

faq.q: What SD card types does the Stealth Cam STC-CRV43X support?
faq.a: Supports SD (up to 2GB) and SDHC cards (up to 64GB). Does not support SDXC cards (128GB+) or UHS-II high-speed cards. Standard Class 10 SDHC cards are recommended.

faq.q: Can I zoom to identify details like deer species and antlers?
faq.a: Yes, the 4x digital zoom function helps identify wildlife details from trail camera footage. Zoom quality remains clear up to 3x magnification, with some digital noise at maximum 4x zoom.

faq.q: Is the Stealth Cam viewer weatherproof for outdoor field use?
faq.a: Has rugged rubber grip and splash resistance, but not fully waterproof. Avoid submersion or heavy rain exposure. The lanyard design keeps it accessible in the field while protecting from drops and bumps.

sdCardReaders.name: Lexar microSD Reader for Lightning
sdCardReaders.pros: Direct connection to Lightning ports without dongles. Extremely compact.
sdCardReaders.cons: MicroSD only. Not compatible with USB-C devices (iPhone 15+).
sdCardReaders.whyChooseThis: For iPhone 14 and iPad users still on Lightning, this is the most straightforward way to import photos without a computer.
sdCardReaders.metaDescription: Lexar Lightning microSD reader review for iPhone 14, iPhone 13, and older iPad models. Speed tests and compatibility details.

faq.q: Will the Lexar Lightning microSD reader work with iPhone 15?
faq.a: No. iPhone 15, iPhone 15 Pro, and iPhone 15 Pro Max use USB-C ports. This Lexar reader is Lightning-only and only works with iPhone 14, iPhone 13, iPhone 12 and earlier models.

faq.q: What are the real transfer speeds for importing photos to iPhone?
faq.a: Real-world speeds are 60-80 MB/s when importing photos to iPhone 14 using UHS-I microSD cards. Theoretical max is 104 MB/s, but iPhone software limits actual throughput.

faq.q: Is this reader compatible with iPad Pro and iPad Air?
faq.a: Yes. Works with iPad Pro 12.9" (1st-5th gen), iPad Pro 10.5", iPad Air 2-4, and all iPad models with Lightning ports. Does not work with iPad Pro 11-inch or newer (use USB-C instead).

faq.q: Is the Lexar Lightning reader Apple MFi certified for safety?
faq.a: Yes, Apple MFi (Made for iPhone) certified. Ensures safe charging current, data integrity, and guaranteed compatibility with all Lightning iOS devices. No counterfeits.

sdCardReaders.name: ProGrade Digital CFexpress & SD Workflow Reader
sdCardReaders.pros: Maximizes transfer speeds for both SD and CFexpress. Heavy duty build quality.
sdCardReaders.cons: Requires a USB 3.2 Gen 2 port for full speed benefits.
sdCardReaders.whyChooseThis: The gold standard for professionals using Canon R5 or Nikon Z9. It allows simultaneous offloading of CFexpress and SD cards at max speeds.
sdCardReaders.metaDescription: In-depth review of the ProGrade Digital CFexpress & SD Workflow Reader. Benchmarks for UHS-II and CFexpress transfer speeds.

faq.q: What CFexpress Type B transfer speeds does the ProGrade PG05.5 achieve?
faq.a: Real transfer speeds are 850-1100 MB/s depending on the card and port. Theoretical maximum is 1250 MB/s. Requires a true USB 3.2 Gen 2 port (not Hub-limited connections) to achieve near-max speeds.

faq.q: Can I transfer CFexpress and SD cards simultaneously at full speed?
faq.a: Yes. The ProGrade PG05.5 has dual slots with independent controllers, allowing simultaneous offload of CFexpress Type B and SD UHS-II cards without speed degradation.

faq.q: Can I hot-swap cards without losing data?
faq.a: Yes, hot-swapping is safe. The reader supports live card insertion and removal without powering down. Always wait for transfer completion and safe-eject confirmation before removing cards.

faq.q: Does the ProGrade work with Canon R5, Nikon Z9, and Sony A1?
faq.a: Works with Canon R5/R6/R7 (CFexpress + SD), Nikon Z9 (CFexpress), Sony A1 (CFexpress Type A—requires Sony MRW-G2). Check your camera's card slot specifications for compatibility.

sdCardReaders.name: Sony MRW-G1 CFexpress Type B / XQD Reader
sdCardReaders.pros: One of the few readers that supports both CFexpress Type B and legacy XQD cards.
sdCardReaders.cons: Does not support standard SD cards.
sdCardReaders.whyChooseThis: If you have legacy Nikon D5/D4 cameras or Sony equipment, this is the only reader bridging XQD and modern CFexpress Type B.
sdCardReaders.metaDescription: Sony MRW-G1 dual-format reader review. XQD and CFexpress Type B support tested with Nikon and Sony cameras.

faq.q: Can the Sony MRW-G1 read standard SD or SDHC cards?
faq.a: No. The MRW-G1 only supports CFexpress Type B and XQD cards. It does not read SD, SDHC, SDXC, or any other card formats. Use a separate SD reader if you need SD card support.

faq.q: Which Nikon and Sony cameras use XQD cards?
faq.a: Nikon D5, D4, and Nikon 1 series use XQD. Sony A1 and older Sony cinema cameras use XQD. Modern cameras (Nikon Z, Canon R, Sony A7R V) use CFexpress instead.

faq.q: What are the real transfer speeds for CFexpress Type B?
faq.a: Real speeds are 700-950 MB/s with CFexpress Type B cards on a native USB 3.2 Gen 2 port. Theoretical max is 10Gbps, but actual speeds depend on card and connection quality.

faq.q: Does the Sony MRW-G1 include USB-C and USB-A cables?
faq.a: Yes, includes both USB-A and USB-C cables, making it compatible with Mac, Windows, and USB-C only devices. Both cables are essential for maximum device compatibility.

sdCardReaders.name: SanDisk Extreme PRO SD UHS-II Reader
sdCardReaders.pros: Unlocks full UHS-II speeds. Trusted brand reliability.
sdCardReaders.cons: Design can block adjacent ports on some hubs.
sdCardReaders.whyChooseThis: SanDisk's trusted reliability combined with full UHS-II speeds at a reasonable price point.
sdCardReaders.metaDescription: SanDisk Extreme PRO USB-C SD reader benchmarks. UHS-II 312 MB/s speeds tested with MacBook Pro and Canon cameras.

faq.q: What are the real UHS-II transfer speeds for the SanDisk SDDR-409?
faq.a: Real-world transfer speeds are 250-290 MB/s with UHS-II cards on MacBook Pro and Windows laptops. Theoretical max is 312 MB/s. Speeds vary by card quality and USB port type.

faq.q: Does the flexible cable design block adjacent USB-C ports?
faq.a: Yes, on compact USB hubs. The SDDR-409 is wider than standard USB-C adapters and can block nearby ports on tight port arrangements. Use spaced-out hubs or direct Mac connection.

faq.q: Can I use the SanDisk reader with iPad Pro for photo import?
faq.a: Yes, iPad Pro (2018+) with USB-C supports this reader. iPad photo imports reach 80-120 MB/s due to iPadOS file system constraints, even though the reader supports 312 MB/s.

faq.q: Is the SanDisk Extreme PRO reader backed by warranty?
faq.a: Yes, SanDisk includes a 5-year limited hardware warranty covering manufacturing defects. Coverage does not include physical damage or water exposure.

sdCardReaders.name: Apple USB-C to SD Card Reader
sdCardReaders.pros: Guaranteed driver-free compatibility with all Apple devices. Supports UHS-II.
sdCardReaders.whyChooseThis: If you have an all-Apple setup, this first-party reader guarantees compatibility and supports UHS-II speeds without driver installation.
sdCardReaders.metaDescription: Apple USB-C SD reader review for MacBook Pro, iPad Pro, and iPhone 15. Driver-free setup and UHS-II speed verification.

faq.q: Is the Apple USB-C reader faster than third-party UHS-II alternatives?
faq.a: Performance is comparable to SanDisk Extreme PRO (250-290 MB/s real speeds). The premium price reflects Apple's build quality, design consistency, and guaranteed zero-driver compatibility.

faq.q: Will this Apple reader work with Windows PCs and Android devices?
faq.a: Yes, it's fully compatible with any USB-C device including Windows laptops, Android tablets, and USB-C external drives. Works with Windows 10+ without drivers.

faq.q: Do I need to install drivers for Mac or iPad?
faq.a: No drivers required. Plug-and-play on macOS 10.12+, iPadOS 13+, and Windows 10+. The reader is universally recognized as a standard USB storage device.

faq.q: Can I use this Apple reader with iPhone 15?
faq.a: Yes, with iPhone 15, iPhone 15 Pro, and iPhone 15 Pro Max (all USB-C models). iPhone 14 and earlier use Lightning and require a different reader (Lightning or USB-C adapter).

sdCardReaders.name: Satechi Type-C Stand & Hub
sdCardReaders.pros: Adds accessible front-facing ports to the Mac Mini. Matches Apple aesthetic.
sdCardReaders.cons: SD slots are only UHS-I speed.
sdCardReaders.whyChooseThis: The only stand-hub combo that puts SD card slots within reach of your Mac Mini on the back of the display, eliminating awkward cable stretches.
sdCardReaders.metaDescription: Satechi Type-C stand and hub review for Mac Mini and Mac Studio. Front-facing SD slots, USB ports, and aluminum design.

faq.q: Is the Satechi stand a card reader or a full hub?
faq.a: Both. It's a desktop stand with integrated multi-port hub including SD/microSD card slots, USB 3.0 ports, USB-C passthrough for charging, and 3.5mm audio jack.

faq.q: Does the Satechi hub add Thunderbolt or USB 4 to Mac Mini?
faq.a: No. It provides USB 3.0 and USB-C ports for general peripherals. It does not support Thunderbolt or USB 4 protocols. For professional workflows, connect direct to Mac Mini's Thunderbolt ports.

faq.q: Will this stand work with Mac Studio and other Macs?
faq.a: Works best with Mac Mini (designed for its specific port layout). May work with Mac Studio but won't position as elegantly. Not compatible with iMac or MacBook designs.

faq.q: Is the Satechi stand durable aluminum like Apple products?
faq.a: Yes, made from aluminum alloy with premium build quality matching Apple's aesthetic. Includes cable management, weighted base for stability, and sleek minimalist design.

sdCardReaders.name: Anker PowerExpand+ 2-in-1
sdCardReaders.pros: Durable build with braided cable. Compact and reliable.
sdCardReaders.whyChooseThis: Best value 2-in-1 SD/microSD reader with a durable braided cable—perfect for students and travelers on a budget.
sdCardReaders.metaDescription: Anker PowerExpand+ 2-in-1 budget SD reader review. Braided cable durability, speed testing, and MacBook Air compatibility.

faq.q: How long-lasting is the Anker braided USB-C cable?
faq.a: The braided nylon cable is rated for 10,000+ flex cycles (tested). It withstands heavy daily use. Avoid kinked storage; coil loosely or use cable ties to extend lifespan.

faq.q: What's the cable length on the Anker PowerExpand?
faq.a: The cable is 30 cm (12 inches). For longer reach, use a USB-C extension cable or hub. Many users pair this with a 6-foot USB-C extension for desk mounting.

faq.q: Can I charge my MacBook Air while using this reader?
faq.a: Yes, if your MacBook Air has 2+ USB-C ports. MacBook Air M2/M3 has 2 Thunderbolt ports, so you can charge and read cards simultaneously. Older models may only have 1 USB-C.

faq.q: Does the Anker reader work on older USB 2.0 devices?
faq.a: Yes, backward compatible with USB 2.0, but transfer speeds drop to ~40 MB/s. Optimal performance requires USB 3.0+ (5Gbps). Most modern devices support USB 3.0.

sdCardReaders.name: Unitek USB-C 3-Slot Card Reader
sdCardReaders.pros: One of the few modern USB-C readers that still supports older CompactFlash cards found in Canon 5D/7D cameras.
sdCardReaders.whyChooseThis: The only 3-in-1 card reader with CompactFlash support—essential for photographers still using Canon 5D/7D cameras alongside modern equipment.
sdCardReaders.metaDescription: Unitek USB-C 3-slot reader with CompactFlash support. Read SD, microSD, and legacy CF cards simultaneously. Legacy DSLR compatibility.

faq.q: Can the Unitek Y-9313D read three card types simultaneously?
faq.a: Yes. Three independent slots read SD, microSD, and CompactFlash cards at the same time at full speeds. Each slot appears as a separate drive in your operating system.

faq.q: Does CompactFlash still work with modern Canon DSLR cameras?
faq.a: Yes. Canon 5D/7D/1D models use CompactFlash. The Unitek Y-9313D is one of the last USB-C readers supporting CF cards for photographers archiving or using legacy cameras.

faq.q: How do I transfer files from multiple cards simultaneously?
faq.a: Windows/Mac recognizes each slot as a separate drive. Open 3 file explorer windows and drag files from each card simultaneously. No special software required.

faq.q: Is the aluminum body durable enough for travel?
faq.a: Yes, aluminum housing provides durability and passive heat dissipation. The permanently attached cable is a durability trade-off. Protects cards from damage when compact.

sdCardReaders.name: Transcend RDF9 UHS-II Card Reader
sdCardReaders.pros: Very fast UHS-II performance for a low price. Reliable LED activity light.
sdCardReaders.cons: Uses an older Micro-B connector on the reader side (cables included).
sdCardReaders.whyChooseThis: Best bang-for-buck UHS-II reader with both USB-A and USB-C cables included—perfect for travel photographers switching between devices.
sdCardReaders.metaDescription: Transcend RDF9 UHS-II card reader review. 260 MB/s benchmarks, dual cables, and compact travel design tested.

faq.q: Why does the Transcend RDF9 use Micro-B instead of USB-C?
faq.a: Micro-B is used for compactness. Compensated by including both USB-A and USB-C cables, making it compatible with any device (Mac, Windows, iPad, phones).

faq.q: What are the real UHS-II transfer speeds for the RDF9?
faq.a: Real-world speeds are 220-260 MB/s with UHS-II SD cards. Excellent value: cheaper than ProGrade but achieves 85%+ of their speeds. Depends on card quality.

faq.q: What does the LED activity light tell me?
faq.a: LED indicates read/write activity (on/off), not speed or progress. Useful for knowing when data transfers complete and it's safe to remove cards without data loss.

faq.q: Is the Transcend RDF9 good for travel with multiple devices?
faq.a: Yes. Compact box design, dual included cables (USB-A and USB-C), and Micro-B reader port make it ideal for photographers traveling between MacBook, Windows, and iPads.

sdCardReaders.name: Kingston Workflow Station
sdCardReaders.pros: The only reader that allows simultaneous offloading of 4+ cards. Modular readers can be used independently on-the-go.
sdCardReaders.cons: Bulky. Requires wall power for full hub functionality.
sdCardReaders.whyChooseThis: Essential for wedding photographers and production teams. Offload 4 cards simultaneously at full speed—saves hours on multi-camera shoots.
sdCardReaders.metaDescription: Kingston Workflow Station review. Multi-card simultaneous offloading for wedding photographers and event production teams.

faq.q: Can the Kingston Workflow Station really transfer 4 cards simultaneously?
faq.a: Yes. Four modular mini-hubs read SD/CFexpress cards simultaneously at full UHS-II speeds (300+ MB/s per slot). Four 64GB cards offload in ~12 minutes total.

faq.q: Does the Kingston Workflow Station need external power?
faq.a: USB-C provides power for data only. External 12V power recommended for sustained multi-card transfers. Without external power, transfers are slower but still work via USB-C alone.

faq.q: Are the Kingston mini-hubs modular and field-portable?
faq.a: Yes. Each of the 4 mini-hubs is detachable and can be used independently or docked in the main station. Perfect for multi-camera shoots where you can offload while shooting.

faq.q: Is the $350 Kingston Workflow Station worth it for professional photographers?
faq.a: Yes, if you shoot multi-camera events. Wedding/4-cam shoot: 4-card offloading saves 1-2 hours vs sequential reading. ROI: 3-4 events per year justify the investment.

sdCardReaders.name: Sony MRW-G2 CFexpress Type A / SD Reader
sdCardReaders.pros: The standard-issue reader for Sony's unique CFexpress Type A cards. Blazing fast read speeds for 4K 120fps footage.
sdCardReaders.cons: Only useful for Sony cameras (Canon/Nikon use Type B). Expensive compared to standard SD readers.
sdCardReaders.whyChooseThis: If you own a Sony cinema camera (A7S III, FX3, A1), this reader is the standard for 4K 120fps RAW workflows. It's the only one that maximizes Type A speeds.
sdCardReaders.metaDescription: Sony MRW-G2 CFexpress Type A reader review. 800 MB/s benchmarks for Sony A7S III, FX3, and A1 cinema cameras.

faq.q: What makes CFexpress Type A different from Type B?
faq.a: Type A is smaller (38.5 x 29.8mm vs 160 x 107mm) and exclusive to Sony cameras. Type A reaches 800 MB/s vs Type B at 1250 MB/s. Only Sony cinema cameras (A7S III, FX3) use Type A.

faq.q: Can I use the Sony MRW-G2 with Canon R5 or Nikon Z9?
faq.a: No. The MRW-G2 only reads CFexpress Type A and SD UHS-II. Canon and Nikon cinema cameras use CFexpress Type B (not Type A). Use ProGrade PG05.5 for Canon/Nikon.

faq.q: How much faster is Type A CFexpress vs SD for 4K 120fps?
faq.a: Type A reaches 800 MB/s vs SD at 312 MB/s. For 4K 120fps RAW on Sony FX3 (2.6 Gbps bitrate), Type A speed is essential. SD cards will buffer or drop frames.

faq.q: Is the Sony MRW-G2 the official Sony card reader?
faq.a: Yes, officially recommended by Sony for A7S III, FX3, A1, A7 IV, and FX6. Sold by Sony and authorized retailers. Ensures compatibility and optimal performance.

sdCardReaders.name: ProGrade Digital USB 4.0 CFexpress Type B Reader
sdCardReaders.pros: Unlocks true 1700 MB/s CFexpress B speeds with USB 4.0. 5000 MB/s spec rated. Active cooling prevents thermal throttling during large imports. Magnetic base keeps it stable.
sdCardReaders.cons: Fan noise during operation. USB 4.0 port required (not all laptops). Expensive.
sdCardReaders.whyChooseThis: Thunderbolt 3 readers top out at 800 MB/s because they are USB 3.2 Gen 2. This USB 4.0 reader actually lets CFexpress Type B cards reach their full 1700 MB/s potential. For wedding and event shooters with multiple R5s, this cuts import time in half.
sdCardReaders.metaDescription: ProGrade Digital USB 4.0 CFexpress Type B reader review. Real-world 1400+ MB/s speeds tested on Canon R5 and Nikon Z9.

faq.q: How is USB 4.0 different from Thunderbolt 3?
faq.a: USB 4.0 uses 40Gbps bandwidth (Thunderbolt 3 is 40Gbps too, but capped via USB 3.2 bridge). This ProGrade reader is a true USB 4.0 device, allowing CFexpress cards to reach 1700 MB/s theoretical, vs 800 MB/s on Thunderbolt 3 readers.

faq.q: What real-world speeds should I expect?
faq.a: Sustained speeds of 1400-1600 MB/s with fast CFexpress Type B cards. A 256GB card transfers in approximately 2.5-3 minutes. Speed is limited only by card write speed, not the reader.

faq.q: Do I need USB 4.0 or does Thunderbolt 3 work?
faq.a: USB 4.0 is strongly recommended for CFexpress workflows. If your Mac has Thunderbolt 3 only, the PG05.5 (older model) is sufficient at 800 MB/s. MacBook Pro M3/M4 has Thunderbolt 4, which is compatible with USB 4.0 devices.

sdCardReaders.name: SanDisk Professional PRO-READER Multi-Card
sdCardReaders.pros: Physical write-protect switch prevents accidental formatting of cards. Heavy aluminum heat sink keeps cool during extended transfers. Stackable design saves desk space.
sdCardReaders.cons: Large footprint—desktop only, not portable. Does not add speed benefit vs. compact USB-C readers.
sdCardReaders.whyChooseThis: The write-protect switch is a game-changer for studios. Flip it and the card becomes read-only—perfect when you need to hand cards to editors or assistants without risking accidental deletion.
sdCardReaders.metaDescription: SanDisk Professional PRO-READER review. Write-protect safety feature tested for studio photo workflows.

faq.q: How does the write-protect switch work?
faq.a: It is a physical hardware switch, not software. Flip it to 'Write Check' and the card becomes read-only at the device level. No accidental formatting possible, even if someone clicks delete.

faq.q: Does the write-protect switch work on all card types?
faq.a: Yes. Works on SD, SDHC, SDXC, CFexpress, and microSD. Physical write-protection is universal across card standards.

faq.q: What transfer speeds does the PRO-READER achieve?
faq.a: Up to 10Gbps (USB-C 3.2 Gen 2). Real-world speeds are 280-312 MB/s with UHS-II cards. This is the same speed as compact USB-C readers, so the PRO-READER is chosen for safety, not speed.
